verses.text: When Nicanor heard that Judas and his companions were gathered in the regions of Samaria, he decided to attack them with all his might on the day of rest.
verses.comment: Nicanor plans his attack on the Sabbath, showing contempt for the holiness of the day (see Exodus 20:8-10).

verses.text: The Jews in his company pleaded with him not to do so and not to violate the laws of their ancestors by slaughtering them on such a sacred day.
verses.comment: The people appeal to the ancient law, emphasizing faithfulness to divine worship even under threat (Ex. 31:14).

verses.text: But Nicanor rejected their requests and arrogantly declared he would fight and trample their traditions, as long as there was a ruler from the kingdom.
verses.comment: Nicanor's pride mirrors the rebellious opposition to divine authority (cf. Wisdom 1:18).

verses.text: When he had made this decision, Judas’s troops, though facing imminent danger, prayed to God, asking the Lord to help them, since they cherished the holiness of the Sabbath.
verses.comment: Their prayer acknowledges dependence upon God, highlighting the sacredness of Sabbath observance.

verses.text: They cried out, 'You, Lord, who through your prophets commanded that the Sabbath should be kept sacred, now protect us from this desecration, and do not let us fall before those who dishonor you.'
verses.comment: Their prayer ties obedience to the law directly to God’s glory and protection (Isa. 58:13).

verses.text: Nicanor, full of arrogance, decided to display the trophies from his victory over Judas and his troops for all to see in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Nicanor’s planned show of triumph in Jerusalem heightens the drama and illustrates pride opposing the people of God.

verses.text: But Maccabeus trusted completely in the help of the Lord, and exhorted his troops not to fear the attack of pagans, but to remember past divine assistance and now expect victory from Heaven.
verses.comment: Judas’s reliance on God alone reflects faith found throughout salvation history (Judges 4:14-23).

verses.text: He encouraged them with words from the Law and the Prophets, reminding them of God’s past aid and stirring them to bravery, until he filled them with courage and readiness to lay down their lives for the law and their homeland.
verses.comment: Judas cites Scripture as both moral and spiritual encouragement, foreshadowing Christ’s own appeals to the Law and Prophets (Matt. 5:17).

verses.text: He raised their spirits by recounting dreams and visions which confirmed that all who perished for the sake of their faith received glorious rewards.
verses.comment: The belief that martyrdom is rewarded echoes Jesus’ teaching in the Beatitudes (Matt. 5:10-12) and the early Church’s theology on suffering and glory.

verses.text: When he finished speaking, their hearts burned with zeal, ready to die boldly, and they formed ranks for battle, with youth at the front and elders supporting them from behind.
verses.comment: The unity and courage of all generations reflect the ideal of community in God’s people and the value of tradition.

verses.text: Judas armed them not just with shields and spears, but inspired them with encouraging words. He told them about a trustworthy dream, a vision worthy of belief.
verses.comment: Inspired visions strengthen their resolve, reminiscent of God’s guidance through dreams (as in Gen. 37:5).

verses.text: He saw Onias, the former high priest, a virtuous man, humble in appearance, gentle in manner, kind in speech, and dedicated from youth to every virtue, with hands stretched in prayer for the whole body of God’s people.
verses.comment: Onias intercedes for God’s people, demonstrating the enduring importance of priestly mediation and prayer.

verses.text: Then in the same vision appeared another man, distinguished by his gray hair and dignity, and marvelous splendor surrounded him.
verses.comment: The description suggests someone of great spiritual stature and honor.

verses.text: Onias explained, 'This is Jeremiah, prophet of God, who loves his people and prays much for them and for the holy city.'
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s ongoing intercession reveals that saints continue to care for God’s people even after death, hinting at the communion of saints.

verses.text: Jeremiah stretched out his right hand and gave Judas a golden sword, saying:
verses.comment: The golden sword is a symbolic gift from the heavenly realms, suggesting divine favor and empowerment.

verses.text: 'Take this holy sword, a gift from God. With it you shall crush your enemies.'
verses.comment: The sword represents God’s powerful word and assistance; the symbolism foreshadows spiritual warfare (cf. Heb. 4:12).

verses.text: Encouraged by Judas’s words, noble in spirit and ready to die courageously, their excitement reached such heights that they could not be swayed by threats, and they determined to fight valiantly.
verses.comment: The people’s noble spirit links martyrs and warriors throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Since the city, the Temple, and the Law were in danger, he feared more for the holiness and glory of the Temple than for his own family.
verses.comment: Judas’s priorities uphold the spiritual values of worship and communal identity above personal interest.

verses.text: Those left in the city were deeply troubled about the result of the battle at the open field.
verses.comment: The people’s anxiety reveals their dependence on divine protection and the importance of prayer for those fighting.

verses.text: While everyone awaited the final outcome, and foreign troops were drawn up in battle formation with their elephants and cavalry in strategic positions and covered with armor,
verses.comment: The scene recalls many times when God’s people faced overwhelming odds yet prevailed by faith.

verses.text: Judas, looking up to Heaven, called upon the Lord, who works miracles, knowing victory comes not through arms but by God’s decision, as the Law records about David and Goliath.
verses.comment: Judas’s prayer aligns with biblical precedent (David vs. Goliath in 1Sam. 17:45-50), connecting victory to faith.

verses.text: 'O Lord, you sent your angel in the time of Hezekiah, king of Judah, and he destroyed 185,000 from Sennacherib’s army. So now, Sovereign of the heavens, send your good messenger before us to bring us victory and terror to our enemies.'
verses.comment: The prayer references angelic deliverance in King Hezekiah’s time (2Kings 19:35); faith in heavenly help remains vital.

verses.text: 'Strike down these enemies by your mighty arm and let those who blaspheme your holy people be crushed.'
verses.comment: The call for righteous justice is grounded in biblical prayers for God’s defense of His people.

verses.text: With these words, Judas courageously engaged Nicanor and his troops, aided from above by the Lord.
verses.comment: Victory is acknowledged as God’s work, not mere human achievement.

verses.text: Nicanor’s troops fell in battle, and he himself was the first to die in the fight.
verses.comment: The defeat begins with the downfall of the enemy leader—divine justice enacted.

verses.text: Seeing their leader dead, Nicanor’s army threw down their arms and fled.
verses.comment: The enemy rout recalls similar scenes of demoralization and defeat in Israel’s battles, speaking to divine intervention.

verses.text: The victors pursued them for a long way, striking down anyone who resisted, until they finally defeated all the adversaries.
verses.comment: The decisive victory connects to historic triumphs by faith and obedience.

verses.text: After the battle ended, and as they returned joyfully, they discovered Nicanor’s body, along with his weapons.
verses.comment: Discovery of the enemy’s body signifies total victory and the end of threat.

verses.text: They stripped the spoils from him and cut off his head and right hand, bringing them up to Jerusalem for public display.
verses.comment: Similar to David’s victory over Goliath, the display is a public sign of God’s deliverance.

verses.text: Judas dedicated Nicanor’s head and hand, which he had cut off, facing the Temple, as a sign of the Lord’s help.
verses.comment: The dedication at the Temple emphasizes thanksgiving and worship as essential responses to victory.

verses.text: Everyone blessed Heaven, saying, 'Blessed is the One who kept His dwelling pure!'
verses.comment: The emphasis on the sanctity of God’s dwelling resonates with the spiritual principle of reverence for God’s holy presence.

verses.text: Judas hung up Nicanor’s head outside the fortress, in a visible place, as an unmistakable sign of God’s protection.
verses.comment: Public display of the enemy’s defeat boldly testifies to the Lord’s power.

verses.text: They decreed by public vote never to leave that day without celebration, but to keep the thirteenth day of the twelfth month called Adar as a day of joy.
verses.comment: The establishment of a perpetual memorial links to the cycle of sacred remembering, as in Purim (Esther 9:19-22).

verses.text: So they celebrated with rejoicing on that day, and the land of Judah was at peace for a while.
verses.comment: Peace following faithful victory is a recurrent biblical theme.

verses.text: Regarding Judas’s achievements—his valor, the victories over enemies, and the consecration of the Temple—they are recorded in separate histories.
verses.comment: Reference to additional records underscores the importance of historical memory within sacred tradition.

verses.text: Here, the account will end. If it is well-written and accurate, that is what I desired; if it is poorly done, that is all I could do.
verses.comment: A humble acknowledgment of limitations, as seen in other biblical books (cf. Wisdom 9:14), expresses the writer’s sincerity.

verses.text: Just as it is harmful to drink wine alone or water alone, but good to combine wine and water for refreshment, so, too, the arrangement of stories will delight listeners.
verses.comment: The analogy of mixing wine and water reflects the integration of teaching and encouragement—a subtle nod to a sacramental worldview.

verses.text: So I will conclude here. If the composition is elegant and pleasing, it is what I hoped for. If it is just average, I have done my best.
verses.comment: Modesty in authorship, entrusting any good achieved to divine guidance.

verses.text: Just as it is harmful to eat too much of one thing, so is reading too much without variety; so I hope this account gives benefit and joy. Here ends the story.
verses.comment: Final words reflect wisdom’s call for balance and spiritual nourishment.
